lessonOverview.title: Unit 7 - Lesson 2
structures: B: Yes, I am. / No, I’m not.
B: Yes, he/she is. / No, he/she isn’t.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and name six more actions (dance, sing, jump, walk, laugh, run) when listening and looking at visual prompts.
supportStrategies: (Vocab) Show pictures of actions (run, sing, jump). Say each one. Students repeat and group by “fast/slow” or “quiet/loud” to deepen understanding.
stretchStrategies: Mime Detective: One student silently mimes an action (e.g., jumping, dancing), and others must ask yes/no questions until they guess correctly. Encourage full answers: “Yes, he is.” / “No, he isn’t.”

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can ask and answer simple Yes/No questions using “Are you...?” / “Is he/she...?” and respond with “Yes, I am.” / “No, I’m not.” or “Yes, he/she is.” / “No, he/she isn’t.”
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Model: “Are you jumping?” Mime the action. Students respond “Yes, I am.” or “No, I’m not.” Repeat with peer Q&A using action flashcards.
stretchStrategies: Mime Detective: One student silently mimes an action (e.g., jumping, dancing), and others must ask yes/no questions until they guess correctly. Encourage full answers: “Yes, he is.” / “No, he isn’t.”

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can use the target structure “Are you ___?” / “Yes, I am.” / “No, I’m not.” and “Is he/she ___?” / “Yes, he/she is.” / “No, he/she isn’t.” to talk about actions.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) Display sentence frames: “Is he ___?” / “Yes, he is.” Drill with class using flashcards, then practise in pairs.
stretchStrategies: Mime Detective: One student silently mimes an action (e.g., jumping, dancing), and others must ask yes/no questions until they guess correctly. Encourage full answers: “Yes, he is.” / “No, he isn’t.”

items: The -ing is often forgotten. Vietnamese does not have different forms of the same verb. I like eat rice.

Systematic kinds of silent letters, such as 'magic e' in late or mote, or silent gh in thought and bought, are entirely alien to Vietnamese. They are often acquired as sight words first; the teacher can explain at higher levels.

Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
